title: 104_hr3475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alcohol Advertising Accountability Act of 1996". It includes findings related to alcohol advertising. The Congress found in 1995 that underage drinking is a significant problem, with 11 million drinkers under 21 and 2 million heavy drinkers. A survey showed that a high percentage of students in 8th, 10th, and 12th grades engage in binge drinking. The median age for children to start drinking is just over 13 years old, with 67 percent of 8th graders having tried alcohol. Additionally, 50 percent of teenagers surveyed believe alcohol is a serious issue. In 1993, over 110,000 clients under 21 were admitted to State-funded alcohol treatment programs. Alcoholic beverage companies spent $2 billion on advertising in 1995, much more than the budget of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism. A study found that viewing beer ads on TV may influence young people to drink beer. Almost half of adults believe alcohol industry advertising greatly influences underage drinking, while one-third think it has some influence. SEC. 3. REPORT OF SECRETARY ON ALCOHOL ADVERTISING. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report annually to Congress on alcohol advertising and its effects. A panel will be established to review alcohol advertising in various media and promotional activities related to alcoholic beverages. Public hearings will be convened at least twice a year by the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report annually to Congress on alcohol advertising, with a panel conducting hearings in regional offices over a 5-year period. The report will identify media used for alcohol advertising, total expenditures, audience demographics, and types of alcohol advertising themes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report annually to Congress on alcohol advertising, focusing on the impact on youth, exposure levels, relationship to underage drinking and public health issues, and evaluation of industry-sponsored campaigns. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report annually to Congress on alcohol industry sponsored campaigns addressing underage drinking, drunk driving, and other alcohol-related topics, including recommendations for appropriate legislation.
